meanings.definition: The action or process of imposing something
meanings.sent1: The teacher's imposition of extra homework was unexpected.
meanings.sent2: The government's imposition of new taxes caused frustration among the citizens.
meanings.sent3: The imposition of wearing a silly hat to work made everyone laugh.
meanings.sent4: Her imposition of strict rules turned the house into a fortress.
meanings.sent5: The imposition of silence in the library was a stark reminder to keep quiet.

meanings.definition: A burden or demand placed on someone
meanings.sent1: Carrying the heavy bags was an imposition on his tired arms.
meanings.sent2: The financial imposition of unexpected bills strained their budget.
meanings.sent3: The imposition of having to choose only one dessert felt like a sweet burden.
meanings.sent4: The emotional imposition of guilt weighed heavily on her conscience.
meanings.sent5: The imposition of responsibility on his young shoulders was overwhelming.

meanings.sent1: The sudden imposition of extra work ruined his weekend plans.
meanings.sent2: The imposition of attending the meeting on her day off was unwelcome.
meanings.sent3: The imposition of a surprise pop quiz made the students groan.
meanings.sent4: The imposition of a strict curfew felt like an unnecessary restriction.
meanings.sent5: The imposition of a long commute added to his already stressful day.

meanings.definition: The act of laying on or imposing something on someone or something
meanings.sent1: The imposition of heavy books on the delicate table caused it to break.
meanings.sent2: The imposition of strict regulations on the industry stifled innovation.
meanings.sent3: The imposition of a new dress code at the office led to some interesting fashion choices.
meanings.sent4: The imposition of a heavy workload on the team strained their productivity.
meanings.sent5: The imposition of a new schedule disrupted the usual routine.
